qas.question: What did the colonization of South Africa result in?

answers.text: many unions and marriages between European men and African women from various tribes

qas.question: What was a result of these marriages?
What class were Africans and Mixed Race children considered?
Who was included in the Coloured group?

answers.text: a system of legal racial segregation

context: In South Africa, the period of colonization resulted in <a0_0>many unions and marriages between European men and African women from various tribes<a0_0/>, resulting in <a1_0>mixed-race children<a1_0/>. As the Europeans acquired territory and imposed rule over the Africans, they generally pushed mixed-race and Africans into <a2_0>second-class<a2_0/> status. During the first half of the 20th century, the Afrikaaner-dominated government classified the population according to four main racial groups: Black, White, Asian (mostly Indian), and Coloured. The Coloured group included people of mixed <a3_0>Bantu, Khoisan, and European descent<a3_0/> (with some Malay ancestry, especially in the Western Cape). The Coloured definition occupied an intermediary political position between the Black and White definitions in South Africa. It imposed <a4_0>a system of legal racial segregation<a4_0/>, a complex of laws known as apartheid.
